newsitem.title: BOSNIA: Two Moslems shot dead, another wounded.
newsitem.headline: Two Moslems shot dead, another wounded.

text.p: Two Bosnian Moslems were killed and another was wounded by automatic gunfire from unidentified gunmen in eastern Bosnia on Friday, a United Nations spokesman said.
U.N. police monitors said Moslem-Croat federation authorities were investigating the shooting incident which occurred near a former front line.
"Our officers can confirm there are two dead and one seriously injured male. They are collecting information and observing the police investigation," U.N. spokesman Liam McDowall told Reuters.
The shooting occurred around the village of Laze, eight km (five miles) north of Sapna along the boundary between Bosnia's Moslem-Croat federation and Serb entity.
U.S. and Russian soldiers in the NATO-led peace force went to the scene but could not confirm the account by Moslem-Croat federation authorities.

The federation interior ministry said the Moslems were "ambushed" at about 9 a.m. as they rode in a tractor to cut firewood in the eastern Sapna region. Four more Bosnians who were travelling along the same road earlier had also gone missing, it said.

The ministry demanded that the NATO-led Stabilisation Force (SFOR) "undertake urgent and energetic measures" to protect the village of Laze, which it said was inhabited by Serbs before the 1992-95 war.
NATO peace-keeping troops patrol a zone of separation between the two territories and all weapons are supposed to be banned from the zone.
The village of Laze straddles the zone of separation but it was unclear if the shooting occurred inside the zone.
Last year, violence erupted along the boundary line in eastern Bosnia when Serb authorities tried to block Moslems moving back to their pre-war homes.
Some Bosnian Moslems, prevented from moving back to their homes in Serb territory, have moved into damaged houses in the zone of separation.
